justification: The study used the Temporal Distancing Questionnaire, developed by Bruehlman-Senecal et al. (2016), to measure individuals' general tendency to engage in distancing to regulate negative emotions. This questionnaire evaluates how participants typically respond to negative events by adopting a broad and distant perspective.

The Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ) was utilized to measure dispositional fear. The questionnaire assesses typical responses related to worry, anxiety, and fear, with items that participants rate on a 7-point Likert scale.

The STAXI-II, a commonly used measure in studies examining emotions and risk taking, was employed to measure trait anger. Participants rated the extent to which various behaviors were typical of them, contributing to a single trait anger variable.

The Fear Survey Schedule-II was used as a different measure of trait fear in one of the studies. It includes items that participants rate on a 7-point Likert scale, assessing their fear related to various situations.

In addition to the STAXI-II, the study combined Lerner and Keltner’s 10-item anger scale with the STAXI-II to provide a comprehensive measure of trait anger, capturing typical anger-related behaviors.
